title: Boris Johnson is asking for this election in the interests of upholding democracy
text:
Snap elections often fail to find favour with the voters, but we cannot move forward without one

When general elections loom, old lore gets trotted out, especially about timing. Conservatives are advised to avoid an election campaign that coincides with Ascot races in June, lest the sight of top hats inflames the red instincts of the masses.

Winter elections are said to be bad for Labour, because Labour voters are supposedly too lazy to walk to the polls when it’s cold and dark. In fact, Britain has had only two winter elections since the war – in February 1950 and February 1974 – and Labour (narrowly) won both.
